Bottled: Very full malty aroma, dark dried  fruits, toffee, light roasty, caramel. Notes of sherry. Brown color, quickly diminishing head. Flavor is full bodied, malty, sweet, alcoholic, moderate bitter and with a heavy fruitiness of oily citrus fruits. Roasty components, bitter hop flavors. Nice and well balanced.

Cellar temperature and into a snifter (bottle conditioned). Vibrant, syrupy and oily looking, fiery copper with little evident carbonation. Head little more than a wafer of white that was desperate to stay afloat, Aroma is dominated by caramelised citrus, honey, toffee and fresh baked white bread with just a hint of vanillin and sherry. Initial boozy warmth sets in with the first sip. Brings along a drenching citrus burst that is sticky and sweet along with notes of butterscotch, caramel and dates. Bready otherwise; the body awkward but not as heavy as expected. Finish is far too warming for a beer of 8.5% ABV. Pretty bland overall. A real disappointment. (50cL, BB 25/07/13, Liquor Barons Hillarys)

Golden Pride on läpikuultavan ruskea ja omaa valkoisen vaahdon. Sen tuoksu on maltainen, tumman hedelmäinen, toffeinen, aromihumalainen ja marjainen. Maku on karamellinen, makeahko, hedelmäinen ja hieman rusinainen. Keskihiilihappoinen ja melko tuhti olut. Taattua Fullers laatua.
330ml bottle. Clear dark amber color. Medium size white head. Sweet, honey, malty, mild roast in aroma. Fruity, sweet, alcohol, caramel in flavor. Mild bitter. Not bad.
Bottle at home. Clear copper color with small white head. Light aroma of malts. Taste of malts, little bitterness, some sweetness. Not bad at all.

500ml bottle, bbe 21/12/2012. Pours a clear mahogany brown with a fast receding, bubbly, cream colored head that leaves a little lace on the edges. Aroma is sweet, caramel, a little fig and dried fruit. Taste is sweet malt, overripe fruit, a little alcohol and earthy hops. Medium to low carbonation, mouthfeel is a little on the thin side. Decent, though not wholly interesting.
Bottle from Alko. Copper red color, white head. Strong malty taste with caramel, toffee, nuts, bread, oak and some alcohol. Bitter finish with some alcohol. Great strong ale.
Bottle, 500ml @ home. pours amber with a medium head. caramel, sweet malts in the aroma. sweet, malty slightly alcohol taste
Pours amber with small head. Aroma is roasted malts, dark fruits, nutty. Some syrup. Flavor is alcohol, sweet malts, dark fruits and grainy.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2013 Clear gold to amber colour. Aroma barley wine, caramel, dark fruits, raisins. Taste light heavy caramel and fruity sweet. Finish warm heavy sweet. 7 4 8 4 15Revisited 30.6.2013. Bottle shared by Peter Bognar. Aroma is that of a barley wine, sweet caramel, fruity. Clear reddish amber colour. Taste is strong sweet barley maltiness. Enough balancing bitterness. Good one. Finish is balanced bittersweet. Good beer from Fullers.

Medium strong aroma has sweet caramel malt, ripe fruits, dark bread. Clear ruby red, nice frothy head medium long. Medium body, soft round feel, alcohol evident as warmth, sweet, slight bitterness, some berries. Good and enjoyable.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2014 Pours reddish amber with a very little head. Aroma features most sweetish dark fruitiness with dried fruity notes, especially raisin. Also berries and maltier elements, such as caramel, bread and toffee, are around. Taste is light sweet, initially very fruity, later maltier. The finish is moderately hoppy, dryish and light bitter - very British. The palate is medium to full bodied, mouthfeel slick and smooth. Alcohol is hidden well. Could offer more in terms of hoppy notes, but still a nice, well balanced winter warmer.

50cl bottle from Alko. BBE 12/2013. Amber in color with a lasting, dirty white head. Aroma is bready malt, hops, alcohol, caramel. Flavor has toffee, bread, alcohol, herbs, caramel. Long fruity finish. Alcohol quite strong here. Full bodied, quite enjoyable.

210912. Bottle at home. Pours clear amber with a nice medium head. Aroma some hops, caramel and bread. Slightly sweet caramel malty taste with a touch of alcohol. This was one of my favourite beers years ago, and now retasted it doesnt really disappoint. Not Bad.

(500ml bottle) Pours a very nice amber with off white head and good lacing but for me thats where the good stops for me. It certainly has a complex taste but for my palate was far to sweet and i just did not get on with this.

Bottle, 500ml. Pours a clear copper colour with a modest head that fades quickly. Aroma is of sweet malts and dry fruits, strong and intense. Taste is heavy and complex, very drinkable with lots of character. Great, strong finish. One of Fullers best.

This brew sports a deep amber colour and a creamy head with a yellow hue. A strong malt base in the aroma, nuts and citrus as well. Taste is bitter form the outset, some sweetness is added. A bitter, and tantalizing finish makes for a really good beer.

Bottle from the LCBO. Drink by date in July, drinking it in September - oops! Nice clear reddish-golden with a strong white head. Aroma is big and quite sweet - lots of toffee and lightly stewed peaches, some sweet orange peel and a bit of lightly toasted sugar. Body is full but not cloying. Flavour starts as sweet as the aroma suggests, with toffee/caramel and peach candy prominent, along with a bit of corn syrup and raisin bread, and even a hint of baked spiced apple. It dries out a bit toward the finish, which is moderately bitter, but I suspect the hops wouldve been a bit bigger and provided more balance when it was fresher. But even with some age on it, its a really pleasant beer that nicely straddles the line between strong ale and barley wine.

Bottle (500ml from The Banker & The Barrow Boy, London):
Rich, dry malts with a mix of caramel and toffee straight away, this was quickly followed by a strong fruity aroma that lingered in the background and gradually became more pronounced. Some alcohol but the spiciness of the beer covered most of this. The aroma was a strong one with applea, pear and biscuit.

Rich look with a reddish copper appearance and topped with a white, half centimetre head that has a foamy texture and disappears quite fast.

A strong malt presence to start along with a taste of rich, creamy toffee and an accompanying caramel flavour. There is a fruity apple and pear taste too that is complimented by some spice and a linger, sweet taste of sugar.

Smooth with a medium to full body and a warming sensation when drank. The beer has a pleasant alcohol kick along with medium to low carbonation and a background sweetness.

An excellent beer and one that really packs a punch with a well hidden alcohol content for the most part and well balanced, complimentary flavours. A great beer for sipping away at.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2014 I tasted this a few months after "Fullers Past Masters XX Strong Ale" - still the same joy. Im beginning to feel that English strong ales or strong ales as a whole is worth attention, my attention, it this case after IPAs. Very fruity, sweet, dense (if dense goes under taste tab :) )taste, very aromatic with an exact amount of bitterness. Really enjoyed it. As a bonus comes those rocket earth-sky launching 8.5% degrees :)

november, 2014 
0.5L bottle Spirits&Wine, Spice, Riga
Beautiful and dangerously delicious brew. A bit more caramel flavor and body/alco - and it would be a barleywine. Gentle hopping level with enought malt sweetness to allow yeast produced fruity esters to shine. Pleasant, sweet, light caramel, candy like aroma with semisweet taste pattern. No long lasting aftertaste, a bit alcohol comes out at the end but mild sweetness and gentle, velvety texture is not suposed to be sipping brew, drinkability level- medium to high. Clear, more ambery than coppery in color, small, beige frothy top. Liked.
Aroma of red berries, probably some other fruit too. Full feel in the mouth. Complex hoppy bitterness. Caramel.
Bem forte, gostei, recomendo, mas prefiro a London.

A sweet aroma with a hint of caramel, roast. A bit of alcohol can be felt as well as some woodiness. Quite sweet with a very little bitterness. Full bodied and rather strong. A nice beer for cold winter evenings.
(bottle) clear medium amber with small white head; aromas of fruit, bread; balanced flavour; very good

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2013 Här har de hittat på något gott. Brödig, humle och malt, karamell. Bra kombination med lagom beska.

Har nu öppnat en flaska som legat och vilat i 3 år. Smak och doft av russin, karamell, malt. Rund och fin. Mer av ett dessert öl. Riktigt gott.

500 ml bottle from Jumbo Alto Las Condes. Pours a hazy dark amber/bronze color with a medium grayish-white head that laces well. Strong, malty-fruity aroma, complex with notes of molasses, peaches, strawberries, Amaretto cream, cranberries, hay, buttery biscuit and lots of phenols. Big, overpowering and malty. Intensely sweet, syrupy but well-made. Big flavors of molasses, palm syrup, overripe peaches and liquor. Boozy and heavy. When it warms, the sweetness becomes overwhelming. The hops are barely noticeable. Huge body, thick in the mouth. Finish is long and leaves a warm and boozy sensation in the mouth. As much a Barley Wine as an English Strong Ale. Enjoyable yet a little too sweet.

500cc comprada en Jumbo Copiapó. 
Servida en un vaso English Pint. Hermosa cerveza de color ambar, clara y brillante, con espuma levemente tostada que desaparece rápidamente.
En nariz es bastante escurridiza y débil, sin notas de lúpulo y sólo algunas notas de complejidad a cera de abeja y algo de madera.
En boca se aconseja dejarla reposar y entregar todos sus sabores... no es para tragar rapidamente ya que se pierde mucho de la experiencia.
Notas claras de coñac o aguardiante en barrica, más alcoholica que amarga o dulce. A pesar de lo "fuerte" o alcoholica (8,5%) su cuerpo es medio a leve  y su final es sólo alcoholico.
Carbonatación nula a los pocos segundos tanto a la vista como en boca.
Es para tomar sola o con un buen puro cubano. 
En general no me gustó mucho... si la experiencia que quisiera es como está cerveza, preferiería un pisco añejado en las rocas.

A clear red/amber with small head. Aroma is a lovely mix of bread and a floral tang - a great sniff! With the taste, the bitterness comes through more than the sweet malt, but work together well and are both present in the finish. The body is quite light, but not watery and carbonation is present.  Overall I would say this is a well balanced and wonderfully tasty brew.

Brown 500ml bottle, best before 18 Dec 09, drank on a cold semi-sunny Sunday afternoon in Nov 09. Poured into a batemans branded UK pint sleeve.

Looked good, a creamy coloured foaming head sat on top of a dark mahogany, clear body.

Toasted malts and rich molasses hit my nose, toffee and treacle but without a sweetness, more a prosperous, well-healed, confident air about it. In short, it smells like a rich persons tipple.

That richness carries on into the flavours, very oak wood rather than plywood, delicious, sumptuous and very moorish. I almost forgot it is 8.5%ABV, no wonder it tasted so full, warming and luxurious.

There are few beers in the world better than a well made English Strong Ale and this is up there with the best, I take my hat off to Fullers, this is one well crafted beer and well worth the extra couple of pence I paid for it.
Dark amber colour with small head. Aroma is caramel, dried fruits. Flavour is nuts, caramel, bittersweer finish.
Gedronken bij dutchdrebus samen met benzai. Bruin helder bier. Zoet caramel maar toch is het net niet.

50cl bottle shared with Dutchdrebus and Ansjelaah. Slightly unclear amber color, medium sized off-white head. Smell malts and lightly caramel. Taste malts, caramel, slightly hops, some bitter. Soft carbo, medium body.

Bottle thx to benzai whos at the toilet at the moment. Clear copper colour with a small white head. Smells caramel, hay, barnyard, boiling malts. Tastes heavy malty, caramel, some hops. Okay carbo, full body.

Goldings hops and Golden Promise malt.   
At 8.5% ABV, Golden Pride guarantees a superb range of flavours, that is sure to satisfy even the most discerning of palates

pours amber with a white head. aroma is fruity, with caramel and hops. taste is sweet, well balanced, alcohol, citrus, and oranges. its has a resinous herbal quality, and a good bitterness. strong, intense, and tasty.

Very nice brew.
Pours a thick dark amber colour, dense head wich doesnt faint very quickly.
This Ale is one of a kind, there is alot going on there that reminds me of a strong belgian ale style, this is a cleaner and more refined brew, wich leaves it more predictable and the consistancy is there aswell, I have bought about 12-14 bottles a years time and its always the same.
Do not hesitate to invest in this brew.

0,33l bottle from British Store, Budapest. Clear, dark amber color with non-durable, white head. Honey and alcohol aroma with fruits and herbs. Intensive malty aroma with honey. Sweetness, much alcohol, barley, spices and herbs, a little resin. Heavy sweet taste. Medium body with creamy texture and average carbonation. Grainy, sweet finish with a light herbal flavour. This beer is like a barley wine. Intensive alcohol and grain feeling.

Bottle: Poured a deep amber color ale with a nice foamy head with good retention and some light lacing notes. Aroma of caramelized malt with light dry malt notes. Taste is a solid mix between some caramelized malt notes with a somewhat dry finish. Body is about average with good carbonation and no apparent alcohol. Nice malt forward English strong ale with well balanced sweetness level though some limited complexity.

aroma: Spicy, sweet and sour fruit (orange, banana?), wallnuts.

mouthfeel: Full and oily, soft carbonation.

taste: Tasty, juicy, Biscuity malt, caramel, orange and syrup

finish: More orange, sweet and bitter fruit and peppery and Dry. 

overall: Perfectly balanced, very, very drinkable despite its strength. Excellent brew with big character.

Reddy amber, small tan head. Clear, flat.
Beautiful fruity/caramel malty aroma.
Intense peppery bitterness throughout, which slightly masks some fruity flavours.
Medium palate, enough carbonation.
Brilliantly complex.
Very good, a little too far towards the hopiness for my liking but quite well balanced. One of my favourites.

En fût au Gambrinus, London, Ont.: Sans surprise le caramel domine mais dans un corps plutôt mince, sirupeux. Le profil houblonné est distinctivement florale mais subtil. Des notes de pain grillé accompagne aussi le portrait.

Nagyon tetszetős mély és tiszta rubin szín. Erős almás malátás illat és persze ott tolakodik a masszív alkohol bukéja a sarkában.
Testes édes ami nekem nem szokott annyira passzolni de kíséri egy kellemes nem túl harsány komlósság. A vége édes, ragdós és sűrű. Finom.
Milyen lehet frissen csapról? Hmmm...
Bottled. Pours copper with a small white head. Smells malty and parfume. Tastes alcohol and sweet malty with a similar finish.

Bottle.
Clear dark amber/copper with a dense yellowed head that doesnt lace that much.
Big sweet aroma with syrupy bready and marmalade fruity apricot and orange notes. Some salty peppery leather and pointy hops.
Taste is also quite sweet, but just enough to stay elegant. Decently complex with lots of marmalade fruit, bread, caramel, spice, some leather and hops. Big body with soft low carbonation, but still very drinkable.
A very nice beer!
Smells like honey with a good bitter end to it.  Body is great, its a tender beer for this high alcohol level.  On tap at beer bistro.
Bottle. Amber color. Plum jam in the aroma. Malty sweet, slightly earthy flavor with dried plums and marmelade. Nutmeg in the aftertaste. Likeable.

This beer was really just so moderate in every regard that it is hard to find words to properly describe it. Medium bodied, moderate malty aroma, moderate bitterness, medium length aftertaste, mildly alcoholic flavour, fairly smooth. It was well made, no doubt, but without strong character.
Bottle at home. Deep amber pour, thick white head. Aroma is fruity, some caramel, nuts and toffee. Flavor is thick malty, somewhat fruity and well balanced. A bit simple. Nice brew.
Bottle @ home. Aroma is sweet caramel malt, touch of flowery hops. Flavour is caramel, light touch of bitterness, not very special.

From a 500ml bottle on 15/2/2012. Pours a relatively clear amber with a small head. Has a strong sweet caramel and toffee malt aroma. The flavour follows suit with masses of caramel and toffee, along with brown sugar and poached fruits. This is a real sweet malt bomb, which is tempered by a good dose of hop bitterness at the end. Certainly has some barley wine like character to it. A very enjoyable brew.

Sorry for the german rating, but this is a lousy rating from my "newbie" time (2007-2009), and its not worth of being translated. I just added it for the statistics, and to complete my backlog!

Ins Glas ergießt sich ein kräftig rotblondes Bier mit guter, hoher, langlebiger Krone. Der Geruch ist dominant süßhopfig, leicht alkoholisch. Der Antrunk ist stramm hopfig, sehr sehr würzig, karamellig und leider recht alkoholisch. Der Abgang zeigt sich bittermalzig, würzig, recht herb und wieder zieht der Alkohol seine Spur durch den gesamten Verlauf. An sich ein gutes Bier, aber weniger wäre hier mehr gewesen.
Sötmandel, kryddor och dadlar. Smakrik, maltig men humlefattig. Så vad vi har här är en välgjord men karaktärslös brygd

500mL bottle from the LCBO.  Beautiful clear deep orange colour with pretty much no head.  Aroma is a mix of fruits, grape juice, and brandy.  Sweet caramel and nuts up front, leading to a nice hop bite at the end, with a touch of warming alcohol.  Almost like a barley wine; very nice!

A deep amber coloured beer with a thin, beige head. There are caramel, alcohol and honey in the aroma. The taste is sweet and malty with notes of orange and bread. The texture is oily, the finish is long and bitter-sweet. Its a good one! It will be one of my favourite beers!
bottle. Golden with red tinge. Malty, breads and cereals. Light hops, well balanced. Great smooth mouthfeel. Very nice.

cereal, bread, grass, leather, licorice, rotten eggs, cough drop, banana, vanilla, smoke, red, cloudy, white foam, rocky head, medium sweetness, heavy cloying sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, sticky, average carbonation, astringent, long finish,

I remember hearing this was the base for the vintage ales, and i can really taste it. Very bready, boozy malts. Light hopping, some pine, and resins. Quite a bit of cereals but still the bready, brandy malts are up front. Just loaded with flavor, this is a real treat.

Bottle best before 08 Oct 12.  Nose is sweet and dusty, strong fruitiness and pleasant lemon-meringue-and-grain yeast.  Mellow chesnut body with a noisy beige head that doesnt last long.  Taste is firmly interested in deep malt but brings prickling hops to balance, sweet to start but dries, leaves a very fruity aftertaste in echo of the main course.  Medium bitterness.  Heavy, rough contribution from the booze, but there are earth and toffee tones to compensate for the otherwise thin, filtered feel.  Full-bodied but not fat, has commonalities with reductions and leggy spirits.  Flawed and too brash for the big score, but remains a good one.

50 cl bottle, Sheffield, UK via Waitrose. Clear medium amber, tan head. Very sweet aroma, banana, caramel, honey a faint floral/nutty background. Quite sweet, some brightness from the hops, then more sweet caramel and a very faint alcohol tinge on the finish.

Bottle 330 ml from erzbierschof.ch. Coppery amber with an off-white and brief head. Wealthy aromas of malt, cereals, toffy, fruits, dates and figs. The taste is very malted, rich, perfect sweet and bitter. There is roasted caramel, toffee, dry fruits, figs, cake, also raisin and hints of Port Wine and Cognac. Very perfumed and inviting beer. High-end.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2012 500ml bottle from the LCBO, served ~15C in a Duvel tulip. Aroma: Sweet, grainy malt, candied orange, dusty grass. Appearance: bright copper, clear with an inch of creamy head that lingered and left lacing. Moderate mouthfeel, a little oily. Initially sweet malts, orange, grains, a bit of hop bitterness and some alcohol. Mix of moderate sweetness and bitterness with additional drying from alcohol. Doesnt really hide its strength much. Nicely balanced beer, not as unctuous as an old ale/barleywine style.  Could be a little bigger in flavour but would make a nice strong ale for an early fall evening.

Pours a bubbly clear bronze with nice lingering head buildup.  Aromas of caramel, candied fruits (especially orange).  Taste is big, fruity, and spicy.  Balanced between hefty bitterness and sweetness throughout.  Real peppery character comes through in the finish.  Alcohol is hidden in the background turning up the volume.  Lovely.

Brown bottle, 500 ml, purchased at the LCBO, best before 16 JUL 12, savoured January 3 2012; eye: copper, clear, no effervescence, beige head that falls and turns into a thin sheet, nice lacing; nose: malt, dusty, alcohol, light hops, caramel; mouth: malt, dusty, alcohol, caramel, slight hops, light orange, finale in malt with presence of alcohol, medium body, below-average carbonation, slightly bitter, lightly sweet, alcoholic texture; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 500 ml, achetée à la LCBO, meilleure avant 16 JUL 12, savourée le 3 janvier 2012; il : cuivrée, limpide, pas deffervescence, mousse beige qui tombe et se transforme en une mince couverture, bonne dentelle; nez :malt, poussière, alcool, léger houblon, caramel; bouche : malt, poussière, alcool, caramel, très léger houblon, léger orange, finale en malt avec présence dalcool, corps moyen, carbonatation sous la moyenne, très légèrement amère, légèrement sucrée, texture alcoolique; en résumé : bien
Nice amber fizzy colour, small white frothy head. Malty aroma, soft carbonation, sweet flavour, minimal bitterness. Dry but refreshing.
Nice head, floral, grass, herbs scent.  Nicely balanced taste, not too sweet or bitter.  Perfectly bitter aftertaste.  What a great beer.

God damn do Fullers make just incredibly quaffable beer.  Pours just an incredible dark amber with a perfect frothy off white head.  Just how a beer is supposed to look.  Aroma is slightly subdued but mostly malt with a hint of english hop.  Taste has good body, great malt profile and a little bitterness.  Slightly sweet but overall very drinkable and very enjoyable.

The LCBO got a bunch of different Fullers this Christmas, and this is one of them. Pours a deep amber colour with a big creamy beige head, great retention and foamy lacing all-around. Big nose of bread, caramel, dark fruits with hints of molasses and citrusy hops. Seems like a warming mouthfeel at first, but really just goes through in a wet fashion. No burning, wondering were the alcohols at ?? The taste is a bit bitter with lots of grain, reminding me or rye, with notes of raisins, orange zest, plums, brown sugar and the grain coming back, lingering in the aftertaste. Not bad at all and too easy to drink. Really, where is the 8.5% ABV ?

medium amber with a thin but lasting head. smell is a bit of alcohol, a lot of grain. i taste a full base grain maltiness, medium caramel taste but dry, nice fruity hops ranging from orange to melon. feels carefully put together and complex. thick and slick body. would definitely get it again

Dark brownish orange, small silky orange tinted white head.  Nice sweet malt and fruit aroma.  taste is excellent - sweet, citrus, biscuit, lots of hops in finish.  Very smooth silky mouthfeel.  Dangerously easy to drink.  Wow, an eye opener, maybe my favourite yet from this masters series we have on our shelves this Holiday season.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2016 Pours deep amber.  2 fingers of puffy white head.  Good lacing.  Aroma of caramel malt, floral, dried fruits.  Taste of Caramel/bready malts followed by a blast of floral hops.  Dried fruits (Raisin) as well as a slight bit of leather.  Medium bodied, lower carbonation, very drinkable.

500 ml bottle from LCBO, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. 29NO11. 
App.:  Deep copper-mahogany, clear, nice light tan head.
  
Aroma:  Thick, rich, sweet, fruity, tones of brown sugar and caramel/toffee/treacle, stewed dark dried fruits, a touch boozy, really big and rich, so malty!
  
Palate:  Medium+ body, medium-full effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Like the nose  a huge wallop of sweet, fruity, boozy malts, orange peel, rye bread crust, sticky and thick, brown sugar, caramel/toffee, dark dried fruits with some brighter notes, stinging alcohol; sweet with limited bitterness, lots of alcohol, fruitier-than-expected finish, bread crust, bitter orange peel.

A was expecting a Blond/Golden Ale...this is BIG!

Bottle from Galeria Kaufhof, Alexanderplatz, Berlin. Pours a deep cognac-hued bronze body with a small white head. Nose is nougat, deep malty tones, wood, vanilla and caramel with hints of crisp noble hops. Taste is strong and deep malty notes, with caramel, burnt toast, nuts and bread all present. In addition, crisp English hops make sure the balance is maintained. Hints of raisins and dried fruits. Dry finish, medium carbonation. All in all another classic from Fullers, whom I respect more and more for every beer I taste.

Much different than the cask version i had 2 years ago.  It had an excellent head and lacing on a light golden body.  Caramal pronounced but so is the bitterness in the finish, toasting.  Lots of flavour, an imperial British!Above average mouthfeel.

Love this stuff. Pours a clear orange with a fizzy head. The aroma is sweet, toffee, candied orange, booze, biscuit. The flavour is also sweet, with toffee and candied orange flavours up front, booze, pepper and a light touch of hops in the finish. Syrupy mouth feel. I thoroughly enjoyed it.
Really liked this one. Bottle from LCBO. Pours dark orange. Big initial malty breaded aromas, backed up by plums and maybe a hint of orange. Medium carbonation and medium body in mouth.

Den gör inte mycket väsen av sig i början men när humlen slår på så händer det grejer. Humlen är mer robust än vad jag är van vid (och jag är mer van vid amerikanska humlesorter) och den är härligt kraftig både till kropp och smak. Efterbeskan är något kort men ack så behaglig.

500ml bottle 
8.5% ABV 
I tried this beer on November 20, 2011 after purchasing from the Queens Quay LCBO outlet in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.  The beer pours a translucent dark reddish gold colour with a thin rocky tan cap.  The aroma was grains, sweet malt, caramel, and floral hops.  The mouthfeel was medium bocied with medium carbonation.  The flavour was cereal, sugar, and grains.  Has a lot in common with a North American Stock Ale. Definitely not my favourite beer from Fullers.
500ml bottle. Pours amber/red with a thin off-white head. Aroma of malt, hops and subtle hints of fruit. Flavour is malt, subtle hops and fruit. Pretty good.

500 ml bottle from LCBO.  Pours a dark golden orange with modest-sized white head.  Aroma is caramel, lots of fruit (mostly pear/apple, but some citrus and a little dark fruit) and a little graininess.  Flavour has pear, some citrus, pepper and caramel.  Alcohol comes through a little in the finish but still easy-drinking.  Nice.
500 ml bottle from LCBO.  Pours brownish copper in colour, with small whitish coloured head.  Aroma is malty, taste is slightly bitter malt, fairly evident alcohol notes.  Meh.

500ml bottle. Served at room temperature. Pours clear red gold and looks great. Head doesnt last long but thats ok. Smells awesome. Aroma is of something similar to sherry. Sweet and warm (spices), alcoholic, fruity and malty. Initial taste is smooth, well balanced, alcoholic, warming spices, sweet, fruity. Malty taste comes through with butterscotch or some kind of creamy caramel desert. I would pick this as a desert beer or it could easily compliment a dish which required a bit of smooth fruity sweetness. Good work. Drank this on a cold summers windy evening in Wellington. Almost 9pm and the sun is still out.

500 mL bottle from the LCBO, served in an English pint. Pours clear copper with a moderate off-white head. The head fades to a thin cover and leaves a moderate amount of fine lace. The nose has notes of citrus, caramel, pale malts, pine and earth. The flavour is moderately bitter throughout with pine and resinous hops. Hops are well balanced with toasted English malts and caramel. Peppery alcohol is a constant background presence. The finish is long and peppery with caramel malts and pine. On the palate, it is medium in body with a dryish milky texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is an excellent strong English ale. It is very well balanced, with beautiful malts and piney hops. An excellent brew. 2011-11-19

Amber, minimal head, flat. Aroma has some alcohol, malts, caramel, clove. Full bodied in  taste and palate, reasonable bitter, with grains, malts and almonds. Somewhat dry towards the finish.Very nice but a bit dominaiting alcohol.
Pours a bronze colour and has aromas of dark fruits orange peel and has flavors of dark fruits orange peel spice malt plenty of flavor nice stuff.

Short lived, off-white head that stays as a film. Hazy orange body. Aroma of sweet boiled vegetables, Alcohol, candy and caramel. Full bodied and syrupy with candy sweet and sprucy, light bitter flavors.

Deep golden-amber pour with a thin head. The aroma is great. Lots of stewed fruit, apple and some pale malt as well. Strong and bracing with a nice warming peppery character. A little bit of orange and a lot of bready character. Slightly sticky mouthfeel and a great balance of malt and hops. Slightly minty with a nice chewy palate. I was in the perfect mood for a beer like this one.

Dark amber white head. Smells of wet hay, wild honey caramel and citrus. Tastes of crisp hops and toasted grains, blooming tastes of pale fruit, honeyed malts and lemony citrus. Centering note of alcohol, compliments the structure really well. Feels dry and yet fat, long long tasty citrus and grassy hop flavors.

500mL lickbow bottle. Pours exactly like the picture which is comforting I guess. Smells of creamy chrystal malt and a faint whiff of British hops. Not booze. Flavour has more depth to it, with pale and chrystal malt backing up some semi-spicy hops. Alcoholic bite in the finish. Despite the strength and thicker body, it still has a creamy feel to it and goes down easily. I like how Fullers can produce beers at very high alcoholic percentages which you still want to pound away because of how delicious they are. Gets waaaaay better as it warms. Claims to be ...reminiscent of sweet orange oil. I wasnt aware oranges produced an oil, interesting. Thanks Fullers!

500ml bottle from the LCBO. pours golden with a lasting off white head. big malty nose. big fruity malt flavour. pretty light bodied for its weight but this makes it feel comfortable in a pint glass. great winter warmer. ill be back for more.

500 mL bottle.  (bb 16 jul 12).  More bronze than golden.  Small off-white head.  The aroma is quite malty, leaning toward bread.  Orchard fruit flowers.  No booze!  Complex malt in the flavour, but it isnt heavy.  Cereal.  A touch of fruit.  Balance of sweetness and bitterness.  Enough booze to add body.  Im gonna need a couple more of these.
A very drinkable beer with quite some alcohol it is one of the best beers i have ever tasted.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2012 Bottle from Systembolaget in Strømstad, Sweden. Golden copper colour with a white head. Plum, honey and caramel aroma. Well blended sweetness, and light bitter flavour. A really outstandig ale.
Aroma and taste of sweet malt with elements of alcohol. Ok hops tone in the flavor, but otherwise, no thanks!
Copper pour with a mild earth and hop aroma. A nice malt, hop and bitter flavor. Its a nice refreshing beer that finishes oddly sweet.

Good taste and aroma ,full palate with a medium body and a nice aftertaste .Pretty much as a good ale beer should be .Not the best ale i have drunk ,but you should definitely try it if you are into ales.

500 mL bottle at home into a pint glass.  Amber brown beer with a well formed head.  Smells of alcohol, red fruit, estery and complex.  Interesting stuff.  Sharp, a touch sour and bitter, a bit of roast.  Tastes not unlike Gordons Finest Gold, but perhaps a little more refined.  Still, its a bit too acidic for me.  Not as good as I thought it would be.
Che meraviglia questa golden pride. Splendido ambrato con schiuma traboccante, aroma netto di malto e sentore luppolato, e in bocca spettacolosa, per armonia ed equilibrio...

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2015 Very enjoyable. Too strong to session but a very good ale to sip. Aroma is dark fruit , oranges, and malt. Taste is again oranges . I also get brown bread , nuts and malt. Great finish also. It tops my ratebeer account for a reason. it is the best of the best. I just wish it was more available in Taiwan.

Bottle from Csak a jó sör. Poured ruby-red, with a tan, creamy lacing foam. Honey, caramel, plum, raisins, yeast, and perhaps some herbs in the nose. There is a slight citrusy hint lurking somewhere in there, but the (delicious) hops kind of overpower it. Medium dense, oily, medium carbonated. Alcohol well hidden, with a sweet, roasty aftertaste that lasts. Pretty good!

Clear amber/orange/brown liquid, pours a creamy white/tanned sleek head. I have drank this beer throughout my life of tasting beers. The first time it, of course, was very strong and strong in alcoholic content by the taste. Since then Ive had it many times and changed my opinion. But it has always been a good beer. The aromascape is full with malt accompanied by caramel, fruit, orange, alcohol, wood, cognac/whisky.. a very unique and somewhat mystic blend. The bitterness is extremely crispy and leveled, and the sweetness finishes of the taste with a tingle. The body is medium but feels really full in context. The texture is surprisingly thin in reality compared to what the entirety feels like with its fullness. A very, very good beer from Fullers. There are not that many of these kind of beers around, and even in those circles it is a very unique one.

Sweet orange flavours. Quite a full-on experience when first sipping - lots of caramel, fruit and alcohol (but not too much). The pleasure lasts the whole bottle and I certainly havent tired of it since I first came across it. Its a great strong ale. One bottle per session though!

Bärnstensfärgad med lågt skum. Doft av mogna äpplen och plommon, svartvinbär, toffee och honung. Maltigt söt smak men en beska som balanserar. En välavvägd engelsk stong ale med ovanligt bra humlebeska. Den känns elegant lyx men kostar knappt en tjuga. Starkt!

A - Whiskey with fruity undertones and slight caramel
A - Dark orange, almost red with lacy off white head
T - Sweet with alcohol and light bitter finish
P - Full to medium and soft
O - A great strong ale

Olyan a színe, mint a frissen kibontott vadgesztenye héjának, még csillog is, ha fényféle tartjuk. Habja közepes méretű, drapp színű, szivacsos állagú és elég kitartó. Illata édeskés, melaszos, mézes, fűszeres és aszalt gyümölcsös. Íze is igen édesen, pörkölt mézesen, vaníliásan és fűszeresen kezdődik, van benne aszalt datolya, füge, körte, sok maláta és karamell. Aztán csatlakozik hozzá a gyógyfüves komló, ami egy kicsit visszavesz ebből az édességből. Igentestes, olajos teste van és nem túl szénsavas. Utóíze keserédes, kicsit toroköblögetős, enyhén száraz és kissé fanyar. Érdekes és erős egy sör, mintha angol duplabaknak főzték volna. Én ugyan 35 fokban kóstolgatom, de ez inkább a téli napok söre.

Halt liter bottle pour courtesy of Paul Unwin, thanks Paul!! It pours out clear brilliant deep copper with ruby hues and tan head. The aroma is rich yummy sweet malts, earthy hops, some pine hops and more earthy goodness at the end of the draw. The taste is right up my alley with a smooth modest level of pine hops mixing with sticky firm malt sweetened earthiness and some floral hops thinly ringed around the edges. This is goooood stuff.

Tükrös vöröses borostyán színű főzet, szappanos jellegű kis habbal a tetején, amely elég hamar semmivé foszlik.
Illata erőteljesen aszalt gyümölcsös.
Kóstolása viszonylag csípősen és édes-fanyar aszalt gyümölcsös ízzel indul, melyet karamell, alkohol és fűszeres komló fest alá.
Testessége szirupos és kissé ragadós.
Az édesebb ízeket megfelelően ellensúlyozó befejezése kétszersültes, komlós és kissé likőrös, amely közepes/hosszú utóízt hagy maga után.
Nehézkes és komoly darab, amelynek magas alkoholtartalma viszont végig jól rejtve marad.

British Store, Budapest. Sötétebb barnásvörös, fény felé tartva tükrös és csillogó szín jellemzi, habja pedig szivacsos szerkezetű, bézs színű és viszonylag hamar semmivé foszlik. Illata parfümös, aszalt szilvás, mazsolás és karamellás. Ízében ugyanezek vehetők ki, de lecsengésében a komló enyhe keserűsége mellett a fekete étcsokoládé keserűsége is megjelenik, utóízében is hosszan érezhető az aszalt gyümölcsök és egy enyhén csípős alkoholos íz társaságában. Bizsergető, igazán komoly sör, olajos, nehézkes testtel és keserédes, duplabakokra emlékeztető ízekkel.
My 300th beer. A good, sweet strong ale. But just a sweet, strong ale. Thats all.

0,5 l bottle, Csakajosor.hu
Deep amber reddish beer with a nice medium foamy tan head that never diappeares fully. Honey with fruits, berries in the aroma, alcohol and some light toasted caramel smells. Oily body, thick texture, the berries luxuriates in the flavor, mild toasted caramel brings the lurking hops in the finish. Strong one, nice.
Bottle. Clear Amber with a thin head. Aroma of fruit, sweet malt with fruit and herb. Flavour is smooth warming malts with a slightly heavy feel on the palate. Quite pleasant

Bottle @ home- Pours dark golden with a white head. Aroma of dark roasted malt, some fruit, bubblegum, light smoke. Taste is roasted malt, caramel, berries, some alchohol. Full body, soft carbonation. 170110

Thanks to PaulUnwin for the share.  Pours orange gold with a white head.  Nose is slightly biscuity, with lots of caramel, toffee, raisins, dates, some citrus, and a hints of booze.  Flavor is similar with lots of sweetness, some citrus, and lots of caramel with some boozy fruit.  Medium-thick mouthfeel and generally a nice barley wine.
This one had a lot of shit going on, another one that just didnt make sense to my tongue.  Skip this.
Bottle. Clear amber with medium tan head. Flavour is malt, caramel, fruit, hops, little sweet, little pine, little butter and a little bitter.

Pours red-amber with a quick light brown head. Nose is quite sweet and dominated by brown sugar and apples. Flavor is a bit more tame and a little on the generic side for English ales, but is quite drinkable. Alcohol does not factor. Decent stuff.
Clear amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet malty, caramel, dried fruit and a little alcohol. Flavor is quite sweet and light bitter. Sweet finish with some alcohol. 270511
taste and aroma does indicate the 8.5% abv strength. Vinous overtones, tingling sensation left on tongue. Nice premium strength ale to savour.

dark amber colour. malty w/ faintest hints of red fruits like apples r cherries. had it cold so it was crisp. it is higher in alcohol so hints of raisin. could taste more as it warmed up. it is a big ale but not particularly nice. has an odd, bitter aftertaste that i dont think comes from hops.

Bottle 500ml @ home
[Trade by Dedollewaitor] Pours clear reddish brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt and caramel. Taste is light sweet and light bitter. Body is medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.

Pours copper with a large, slowly fading head.
Nose shows lots of sweet malt: heaps of brown sugar, raisins, bread and butter pudding, golden syrup and a little alcohol. Very complex.
Similarly rich flavours, although the booze is more evident. Big syrupy malt dominates but some nutty hints are introduced along the way. Booze is a little bit too full on.
Soft carbonation could be higher.

Bottled 500ml. - from the London Pride store in Ljubljana, shared with Marko. 
Clear cooper coloured, small off-white head that went away slowly, sweet candy (sugary) nose. Sweet malty, weak hoppy and too exposed fruity taste. Also quite alcoholic. Alcoholic finish with hint of prunes. Another overrated Fullers.

Bottle from the London Pride store in Ljubljana. Poured a copper-brown-amber bodywith a small off white head that went away slowly. Sugary sweet malty nose. Vaguely orangey sweet malty taste, some light alcohol. Hop? What hop? Couldve passed this off as a Faroese beer to us that day. Who are they kidding? This mustve taken a huge hit to explain the difference between what some are describing and this. And the same goes for the 1865.
One of my favourite beers. I love its taste, kind of sweet and bitter with some organe taste...

a little watery, maybe im used to american ales of this abv that are more oily than watery, but very easy to drink, almost no hops to speak of which again is a major difference in this beer than american equivalents that would be a hop bomb. bready, a little too sweet at times, but overall very enjoyable and delicious ale.

Bottle 500 ml. Pours clear deep amber with a creamy off white head. Sweet malt, fruit and spice aroma. Flavour is sweet caramel malt with fruity (prunes) notes. Medium body with soft carbonation. Finish is long sweet malt with caramel and fruit, with solid hop bitterness for balance and warming alcoholic. Very well crafted beer, not to be trifled with though.

Doftar Fullers! Marmelad och kola. Smaken är lite tråkig, söt och inte tillräckligt bitter. Lite för mycket alkoholsmak. Fyllig och lite tjock i konsistensen. Lite besviken över detta öl, hade förväntat mig mer. Doften lovar mycket, men smaken uppfyller inte förväntningarna. Tråkigt. Jag upplever det som en standard Fullers som har fårr mer alkohol och större kropp.
Pours a red-gold with a fine white head. Vinous and oaky nose with honey, beautifully rich and creamy with more honey and a big alcohol bite.  Long warming finish.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2011 Pored from a 500ml bottle, very sweet on the nose of caramel honey over ripe dark fruit and fruit cake Off white head with ruby body medium to full mouthfeel, with a medium carbonation. fullers havde done a great job of masking the taste of alcohol,
un sessionable due to its richness.

Clear golden with a off-white head. The nose have a lot of sweet caramel and butterscotch, but there are also some dried fruit, orange and mixed undefined hops. The rich mouth goes along the same line, just more of it. A nice medium bitter ending. Altogether a very good strong ale at a comfortable price. Ill have more of this one alright...
January 2008  Dry ale. Immediate sweet porty tones mixed with malt and a hint of brandy. Lingering bittersweet finish. More dry malt and a hint of hops. Nice!

Aroma-honey,coffee,slightly sweet maybe nuts
Appearance-Copper, thin off white head
Taste-sweet but also just a little bit bitter. Tates strong in the same sort of way a sweet sherry would (what I mean is like a sweet drink bit with a little kick to it.
Overall- I like this, could not drink a lot of it and for me one 500ml bottle would be my only beer for the night.

01.01.2011. 0,33l Bottle. dark golden colour with a thin layered white head. At first this beer is rich with malt sweetness and notes of strong alcohol. After a few sips it gets more smooth and youcan taste the strength in this beer. Very good.

Pours clear ruby amber with a fluffy tanned head leaving nice lacing. Aroma of caramel, fruits, bread, hops, alcohol, fidges and plums; more like a barley wine. Hoppy and malty mouthfeel. Flavor is fruity, hoppy, malty, alcohol, raisins and port wine. Fruity sourish palate. Finishes with a very nice longlived fruity and tart hoppy aftartaste.
50cl, English brewery, from Slijterij van Bergen Eindhoven, complex brew, not too heavy, balanced, clear, small head, nice brew

33cl bottle from Systembolaget. It poured an dark orange colour with a small creamy head. Some carbonation. Aroma is malty with heavy notes of dough, bread, toffee and perhaps some caramel. Flavour is well rounded, smooth and sweet. Notes of roasted malts, hops, alcohol, caramel and hints of syrup. A short aftertaste. A really nice beer.

Very clear red amber with little bubbles. A nice foamy yellowish head. Hoppy aroma with a little caramel. Very full mouthfeel. A little vinious. A burnt feeling with some toffee. A little plums as well. Warming and pleasant.

Copper with a medium sized off-white head. Aroma: raisins, port, toffee, fruit, some herbs and spices. Taste: caramel, toffee, dried fruit, malty and fruity with a pretty low bitterness and some alcohol. Full mouthfeel.

500 ml bottle. Rated @ 4.3.2010.
Pours a clear reddish brown colour with a creamy white head. Fruits and caramel malts on the nose with citrus notes. Floral hops on the nose with fruits, caramel and strong malty base. Medium bodied with a slick, oily mouthfeel. Pleasant drink which lacks character.

Bottle at Fullers Hock Cellar. Pours a deep amber. Aroma is rich with malt and notes of molasses and dark fruits. Full-flavored and full-bodied with an balance of moderate bitterness and rich malt. Flavor has notes of dark fruit, orange, and toasted grains. Smooth and potent.

Aroma is caramel malts, honey some molasses and dark fruits. Taste is big body malts, sugar, dried fruits, salt and some licorish. Aftertaste is some bitterness which is perfectly balanced making ths a nice brittish strong ale.

500mL bottle.  Pours clear gold with a thin head that settles to a ring.  Aromas of sweet caramel, floral hops and alcohol.  Medium sweetness, mild bitterness and a bit of heat from the alcohol.  Medium bodied, thick, soft carbonation and a short finish.
Bottle. Pours with a small white foamy head, that quickly dissapates, over a clear dark amber/ copper body. Aroma/taste of muscat/port, toast, golden syrup/brown sugar. Full bodied.

from old notes Brilliantly clear maroon hue under a compact white head. Spicy orange and cracked pepper aroma against a cracker and cookie background with a toffee accent and a bit of whisky-like heat; also a bit of peaches and a bit dusty. Thick maltiness, cut by alcoholic thinness and bitterness, fairly high and clean acidity, moderate hop bitterness. Thick and creamy, soft carbonation. Clean and fresh enough, a little hot from the alcohol; nice malts but might not suffer from being drier.

Bottled. Brown color that start with a nice fluffy foam but disappear quickly. Aroma is sweety and malty and alcohol, some Toffee, sugar and caramel. Flavor is pretty much the same as aroma with some bitterness. Mouth feel is medium that keep some bitterness balanced with the sweetness.
Bottle. Dark amber colour with a small white head. Caramel and malt in the aroma. Flavour is very sweet and malty with some bitterness, caramel and toffee. Aftertaste is sweet, medium to full-bodied.

Dark copperbrown beer with medium and beige head. Aroma is strongly sweet, syrup, but still not too sweet, also berries; quite temptating aroma. Flavour is sweet, syrup with nice bitterness and end is almost dry, toffee, wooden hoppyness and maybe hint of alcohol? Full bodied and nicely sticky to drink. Faultless, good and sweet beer, quaranteed Fullers quality.
Bottle from Daily Delis. Dark brown amber with thin, silky head. Nose of malts and chocolate. Taste of malts, chocolate, caramel and brown sugar. Quite nice. Warm, cloying finish.
Bottle from Beers of Europe. Sweet hoppy phenolic aroma. Reddish brown colour with big beige head. Big sweet nutty malt flavour. Too strong for me.
Bottle. Golden, clear with a minimal head. Aroma; malty with some caramel sence. Taste; medium bitter..

Deep amber colour and white head. Caramelly malts, nuts and  toffee in the aroma. Same goes with the taste which has also alcohol in the aftertaste. Tasty but not very easy to drink because of the alcoholic taste.

Bottle 50cl. A clear amber beer with medium carbonation and small head. Smell is on caramel malt and spicy hops. Aroma is on caramel and intensively on hops, a very intense hops bitterness at the finish that remain several minutes. Medium sweet, with a dry finish, the alcohol is present, the malty character is a bit low, hops brings a low lemony and spicy taste with small chocolate notes.

500ml bottle from my mate Wiggy. Clear dark amber pour with a beige head. Aromas of baked apple, vanilla, caramel, toffee. Flavours of malts, licorice, treacle toffee and sweet spices. Big, bad alcohol burn. Almost meth like. Quite hoppy. Good bitter finish. Robust brew with plenty of balls.

500ml bottle.  Pours a deep copper and amber colour with a small head which quickly went.  Aroma is caramel malt, alcohol and some orange.  Very sweet to start, with lots of malt and a medium bitter finish.  Body is very thick.  Really good quaffing ale!
Amber with little head. Aroma sweet honey, malt. Taste sweet fruit, malty caramel, licorice, alcohol.  Medium body, text thick, carb fizzy, finish long bitterness.

Bottle. Its a clear, copper colored beer topped by a diminishing finger-thick beige head. Alcohol, syrupy sweetness, dried apricots and caramel on the nose, rather pleasant. The same goes for the flavor, which is sweet and sugary, with caramel, dried apricots, fresh fruits and a balancing bitterness. Some alcohol too, full-bodied and next to sticky on the palate. Warming, sweet and pleasantly bitter finish. Nice. 100213

50cl bottle: Reddish brown colour with a vanishing head. Very malty aroma with hints of oxidation, yeast and herbal and tobacco-like hoppiness. The mouthfeel is really full, in the flavour, theres a big cookie-and-caramel-type sweetness, which is okay but bordering on becoming cloying - and thats an adjective I dont use inflationary. I mean, if you cant stand sweetness in a beer, you should probably avoid this. I thought it was actually a pretty decent sipper. There was a nice "british" hoppiness and slight roastiness to counteract a little.
Bottle. Brown colour with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malt, hop, caramel. Flavour is alcohol, hop, malt, caramel, dried fruits. Full body. nice beer.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2011 Amber with a large thick beige head. Smells of alcohol, complex toffee, muscatels, spicy, fruity and grassy hops. Big initial caramel sweetness fades into dried fruits then yields to a spicy bitterness. Creamy mouthfeel is just short of syrupy. Malt complexity is subtle and the hops are lovely, but goodness its boozy.

Pours a deep amber with a yellow-white head which lows quickly, leaving a circle of lacing around the rim of the glass.  Aroma is malty with vanilla, marmalade, and an artificial banana sweetness.  Alcohol is present in the nose.  Taste is sugary orange, vanilla, a light zest and pepperiness, bread and brandy.  Mouth feel is sticky and creamy, leaves a good covering on the palate.  Finish is a bit too sweet and doesnt develop on the flavours.  More hops would have been good to counter some of the sweetness, but as a desert sipper this is a good beer.  A little raw with the alcohol considering its only 8.5%, but for the price and availability, its well worth it.

Excellent. A dark amber/red ale with light brown head. Aroma is malty, fruity (plum, cherries), sherry-like, some bread and roasted too. Taste is sweet with an average bitter end. Good carbonation, medium body. 
A great ale.
Pours reddish brown with a medium head. Flavor is fruits and paint thinner. Thick flavor is malts and fruits with some hops in the end. Very nice ale despite the aroma.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2010 500ml bottle bought in Port of Spain, West Bees supermarket.  Pours reddish amber with foamy white head and some, not lasting lace. Aroma of malty dried fruits, slight hoppy bitter and candy. Flavour is thick with traces of sweet malts, toffee, and sugar. Alcohol is noticeable but subtle. Nice lingering aftertaste.  Most probably, the best beer available in Trinidad.

Bottle 50 cl. Pours a clear cherry red with a fading white head and an aroma of red fruits (mainly cherries), hops and caramel. The taste is sweet and syruppy, with hints of ripe red fruits, sweet malts, toffee, brown sugar, some alcohol and in the end theres bitter hoppiness. A really nice beer!

caramel brown white malts fruit hops strong sweet rich fruity orange clear amber thick bitter malty dark colour sugar spice toffee

Bottle.

A - Coppery caramel brown with an average sized foamy white head. Really good retention, especially considering the ABV, that leaves a nice foamy layer of lacing.

S - Some caramel smelling malt serves as a springboard for golden fruit (particularly apple, but some pear too) and some floral and tea like hop aromas. A hint of honey in the background along with a hint of breadiness. Alcohol is just barely present.

T - Similar to the nose. Strong malt presences creates the base for this beer with a lot of caramel and bready flavors coming out. Interplaying with each other are golden fruit (apple, pear, golden raisin) and floral/tea hops. They wax and wane throughout the sip. Also present in the background is some honey, butterscotch, spiced, and nutty (more sweet than earthy) flavors.

M - Medium body with slightly above average carbonation. Pretty smooth.

D - Great drinkability. The alcohol is very well hidden and the flavors are well balanced and none of them overpower the others. Easy on the palate and pretty tasty (dangerously so for the ABV).

Notes: Best before 01/01/11. A solid beer that is a good example of an English Strong Ale. A touch on the sweet side, but it has enough to counterbalance that. Dangerously easy to drink given the ABV. It didnt necessarily blow me away, but it is definitely worth getting a deserve a place near the top as far as English Strong Ales are concerned.

Bottle. Aroma is lots of deep rich hops and lots of malt make this a very well balanced beer. Very fruity, especially orange. Heavenly. Pours a rich clear deep amber with a thick off-white head that dissipates. Medium bitterness, a full bodied brew. Undertones of sweetness balance this out. Rather glorious on the palate. Sweet and rich! Fullers, youve done it again!

clear amber, small white head.
aroma is lightly sour, caramelly
flavor is nice sweet malty, caramelly.

500ml bottle. Dark copper colour with an even layer of dense tan foam. Strong port like aromas burst from the bottle as it is poured. Currants, spiced fruit and plum pudding come to mind. Strong warming flavours that hit all parts of the mouth. Rich and full bodied. Perfect for sipping by an open fire.

Pours copper with light beige fluffy long lasting head. Aroma is malty, caramell, bread, roasted sugar with spicy herbal hops in background. Thick body with lots of toffee with a lingering bitter finish.
Bottle.  Aroma of grains, orange and hops. Dark amber colour with beige head. Bittersweet flavour of malt,honey, caramel and hops. Pleasant body with low carbonation.

Heavy brown 500ml bottle into pint glass. Pour is clear copper coloured with a thick collar of cream/yellow-tinged foam that laces nicely. Strong enticing richly treacly and roasted malt aromas with a hint of alcohol. Flavour is rich medium sweet malts with a bittersweet hop finish. Lovely velvety smooth mouthfeel with a medium to full body and low carbonation. ABV very well hidden (danger!). Another winner from this excellent brewery.
Bottle. Alcohol aroma is apparent from the pour, which is red brown with a rapidly diminishing head. Taste is malty with some orange, a slight bitterness and a finishing alcohol burn.
Bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is dark amber. Aroma and taste are rich malt, fruits, spices and notes of alcohol.
500ml bottle, copper color,white semithick head. Hoppy aroma with citrus and apricot. Flavour has also apricot, caramel and licorique, sourness and some bitterness at the end.

Pours a clear copper amber. Off white head that fades to fine lace fast. Fruity hop caramel aroma. Taste is bit sweet caramel brown sugar. Medium carbonation and body. Smooth, pretty well rounded. Finish is clean and sweet, earthy grainy. Lacks bitterness. Okay brew. Nothing special. I doubt if I would drink it again.

[2652-20091211] Cask. Sweet heavy grainy malt aroma. Clear, dark amber red body with a medium-lasting foamy white head. Sweet thick syrupy grainy malt flavour. Medium body is bitter and thick. Not bad, fairly golden and pridey.
(@ Volo; Toronto, ON)

Bottle. Clear reddish-copper color with a medium, quickly-diminishing, white head. Nice aroma with biscuity malt, toffee, caramel, fruity notes and some hops. Flavor starts with some sweet chewy maltiness and caramel, and continues with a pleasant, somewhat spicy, hop bitterness and a bit of alcohol. Medium-bodied. Pretty good.

Provdatum: 2009-04-05 
UTS: Oxiderad koppar , krämigt skum, persiko färgat skum
Doft: kaffe
Smak: alkoholen dols skickligt bakom den fylliga maltigheten, Perfekt ale. Leta genast upp den ale på tapp.
Rekommenerar köp på enna suplima vätska! 
Anteckningar:

Bottle. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Dark yellow colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Light malty-sweetness and moderate bitter vry well-balanced flavor. Long nice finish. Creamy palate. Much better than many barleywines......

(Bottled) Slightly hazy reddish amber color with a medium, thick and foamy head. Barley-wineous, quite sweet-toffeeish aroma with rye-puddingy maltiness. Medium to full-bodied, slightly fizzy-carbonated, sticky-sugary palate. A quite nice strong ale - although quite sweet and sticky. Not bad at all.

Nice. Pours a deep orange colour, alcohol very noticable at first with elements of butterscotch and licorique. Fruity aftertaste, this is a good beer, maybe if the alcohol was a little more disguised Id go even higher.

Tasted at Den Tatoverede Enke in DK. Was paired excellently with their Sheppards pie.  Not my favourite Fullers beer, but tasty. Pours an amber colour with white head. Taste is quite sweet, with caramel malty body, notes of apricot, cloves and  grassy bitter finish.

0.33L bottle, small stable head, crystal clear and a little pale copper colour, strong aroma of yeast and herbal hops with some earthy notes.
Dominant malty flavours with some nuts and light raisins and a caorse alcoholic presence which is a bit overwhelming and not very pleasant, big bodied. Could be better.
Somebody really like this? I drank Fullers Golden Pride only one time in SÃo Paulo, Brazil and it´s terrible, it taste like washmachine water.....

Bottled 50cl. Caramel, white pepper, leafy earthy english hops, pear, sweat, pop corn, bergamot orange, salt and wild strawberries in the nose- reminiscent of Youngs special London ale with a lot more butterscotch, diacetyl-elements. Caramel accentuated. Nutty and remarkably leafy. Potato components sneaking in. Complex. Sweetish. Low bitterness. Sweet leafy finish which is reminiscent of caramel. Nice, but dissapointing comparing to other beers froms Fullers. Im not a big fan of Cognac. (Michael Jacksons comparison). This beer definitely doesnt deserve a high rating.
A good brew, howerever it has a bitterness I dont appreciate.  It is sweet, and has an asprin-like bitterness.

Bottle from Sainsburys supermarket. Attractive mahogany pour with good fluffy white head. Aroma is oranges/caramel. Tastes of orange, caramel, honey, festive fruits, very rich. A really warming, satisfying and delicious beer and dangerously drinkable. Glad I bought 12 bottles for Christmas!

Pours orange radiant highly carbonated with a huge tan head, aroma of apricot, vanilla, wood caramel with clove-like anf grape fruit peel notes, flavors is very sweet and malty, thick and syrupy, toast, grain, vanilla, wood, quite alcoholic with a bitter grassy finish, medium to full bodied, quite satisfying at the winter.

Bottle. Rich coppery orange-amber with scant head. Aroma is rich, slightly rusty, metallic, with burnt sugar, caramel, jaggery. Nice quaffability, soft palate. Nice burnt lingering aftertaste after a pleasant malty body. Burnt cookie character. Tasty.

Bottle: rich sweet malt, fruity, caramel, some vanilla notes, toasted wood, faint nutty notes, faint coffee notes, faint cocca notes, nice orangy cirtic hoppiness which balances the malt, light alcoholic bite, rich and satisfying beer.

Bottle, found in Saigon. Dull amber-brown colour.  Has a deep, chewy malt aroma showing traces of oxidation.  There are subtle brown sugar accents but in general the aroma is muddled.  Rich, with light brown sugar, light oxidation, some dried leaf notes from hops, and a little bit of pithy hop bitterness underpinning it all.  It lacks the vibrant yeast of a classic example, being pasteurized.  Finishes chewy, with a light booziness and a hint of leafy hop bitterness.

Bottle. Pours a orange copper colour with a slightly off white head. The aroma is all toffee and dark fruit maltiness with some light floral hop notes. The toffee and dark fruit also comes through quite strongly in the taste with some floral hop notes and a bit of warming alcohol, with a dry bitter finish.

Amber colored with brown hues. A very small white head that dissipates quickly and leaves minimal lacings.

Plenty of malts in the nose, sweet chocolate and very light hop aromas. Dried fruits, raisins and quite prominent alcohol, almost solvent-like.

The taste is predominantly sweet. Bold juicy malt character with plenty of caramel notes. Some fruits and raisins. Brown sugar and sweet chocolate. Nutty flavors (almonds), hints of oak. Gentle floral hops and faint spices. The finish is surprisingly short, minimally bitter and is dominated by warming alcohol.

Full bodied, very smooth. Low levels of carbonation. The mouthfeel is actually the highlight of the beer.

A good beer, but nothing spectacular. Its slightly too focused on sweet flavors. The alcohol isnt really that overly prominent, but still it doesnt feel totally integrated with the other flavors. I liked it, but I think there are better strong ales out there.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

50cl bottle, as shown. 

Pours a beautiful mahogany with a medium-sized, creamy off-white head with decent retention and plenty of lacing. 

Aroma is of dried fruit: raisins, some orange peel, plus caramel. 

Medium carbonation and a thick, creamy and oily mouth feel that, at 8.5 % abv, should surprise no one. A full-bodied strong ale, as Ive come to expect from Fullers.

Taste is of sweet roasted malt, toffee, stewed dark berries, with a lot of herbal spices adding to the complexity of this brew - again with a freshening note of orange peel. Malty, full, medium dry finish and gripping, slightly boozy after taste. Very similar to the much more expensive "Vintage Ale", which seems logical if that beer is indeed based on Golden Pride (same abv, to begin with). Unlike the "Vintage" variety, its pasteurized.

As with all the strong ales and premium esbs from Fullers, this one is beautifully balanced, with the strong alcohol well integrated into the intricate fabric of aromas. Sweetness and malty bitterness complement each other brilliantly, If youre searching for the perfect "fireside brew", look no further.

Copper-colored, the foam is a bit dirty white. Aroma was rather inviting, malt toffee, apricot, nuts. 

The relatively high alcohol content of 8.5%, passed through a bit in the flavor. The beer is sweet, body was quite full. Bitterness is pretty high on the beer.

(bottle) Hazy, copper-ish amber colour with a beige and dense foamy head. Sweet and strong Bock-like cara-malty aroma with notes of caramel, subtle fruity notes and almost ethereally spices. Sweet flavour with a balancing bitterness, full bodied with a calm carbonation. Robust (cara-)malty, slightly toasted base with caramel/toffee, liquorice, subtle fruity elements and again almost ethereally spicy notes; sweet and slightly bitter malt-accented, delicately toasted finish with an inoffensive, but very present alcoholic burn in the warming sense. A hearty, very flavourful brew. 28.IX.09
bottle. deep caramel chestnut pour, medium rich maltiness, strong pronounced flavor, warm booziness follows the rich malts, very smooth at 8.5%

Aroma: smells strongly of alcohol, hints of raisins, dried fruit and yeast.

Appearance: Rich tawny hue, head dissipated quite quickly

Flavour: Full on sweet fruitiness followed by a malty, treacley body with a slightly syrupy mouthfeel, finishes with a distinct alcoholic kick, lingering warmth and sweetness.

Palate: Would have preferred a little more range and complexity, the bitterness and the hops are definitely outweighed by the sweetness and alcohol, nevertheless, delicious, if a little hard to drink in large quantities (probably a good thing due to the ABV!).

Overall impression: A very enjoyable, powerfully flavoured beer, will definitely buy again!

Flaske 0,33l kjøpt på Systembolaget i Kiruna. Gyldenbrun på farge. Høyt kremaktig skum. Veldig pent å se på. Fruktig aroma med plommer i forgrunnen. Smaken preges av søt alkohol og mandler. På grensen til sherry. Blir litt uvariert - men bevares: Dette er et godt øl. KI=7

Dark coppery colored with medium sized yellow head. Raisinny and vinous aroma with chocolate and thin spices, mild warming alcohol also comes up. Medium to full bodied, smooth palated. Flavor starts with same raisin-chocolate combination, aftertaste gets vinous with mild alcohol, drying hops and lemon. Fine brew.

Bottle. Pours beautiful golden copper with an off white head that leaves lots of lacing. Nose is very mild but you can detect notes of toffee, brown sugar and a hint of whisky. Flavour is quite similar to the aroma with aded malt, butter, honey and a little woodiness. Mouthfeel is very smooth and creamy and those are excellent words to describe this beer, as well as outstanding, beautiful and delicious.

Bottle. Pours a beautiful deep rusty orange with a thick densely packed vanilla coloured head that leaves early delicate lace. Rich caramel aroma, slightly earthy, with hints of spicy fruit. Very malty palate, toast and toffee with quince and cherry fruit. Woody and spicy notes, mild bitterness. Full-bodied, chewy, with a pleasantly warming finish. Like a baby barley wine! Delicious!

text: bottle, Waitrose Sidmouth 2008. Dark brown colour with a small head. Fruity nose. Very smooth, deeply malty with raisins, plums and shy hints of citrus fruit. Very malty indeed with a well-rounded malty finish. Delicious.

(bottle from Waitrose, Wymondham) Dark brown with very little head, what is left is an off white colour. Smell is plums, red fruit, with some dark malt, alcohol, cherries - very fragrant. Taste is strong rich dark red fruit with alcohol body and a little carbonation. Sweet, syrupy, but not overpowering. Not particularly bitter. A great strong ale.

Fine red to amber appearance. Flavour is light barley wine, the alcohol is apparent initially, but not overbearing and theres some good fruity flavour, tending towards peach and cherry. Warming on the way down, the strength comes through more as it progresses.

Mellow bitter flavour initially then more malts. Has a wonderful balance, but lacks in character. Definitely full-bodied, but the hop bitterness take out most of its punch. Some alcohol character. Not bad, but I feel that there could be much more of everything except body in this beer.

Toffee malts and apple on the nose. Lots of caramel with a touch of alcohol and a hint of dried, dark fruit. Never gets too sweet despite that and the hops, although a bit in the background, provide a nice counterweight.

33 cl bottle from Systembolaget Kiruna (Sweden). Pours dark amber with a small brown head that dissapears quickly. Flavor is malty and some citrus. quite complex this one and with a good solid palate.
Amber color with small white head, nice smell of malts and flowers - strong malty taste and flowery hops , but can olso feel the alcohol here that draws a little bit down, but stll good beer
Bottle from Waitrose. Amber with an off white head. Hops cut through the sweet cloying alcoholic malt base to create a reasonable balance. One of Fullers better beers.

A clear red/copper colored beer, with a thick light beige head. The aroma of fruits, malts and caramel. There are also hops. The taste of thick caramel, not to sweet. Dark brown color with thick tan head. Sweet fruity aroma of dried apricots, plums and toffee. Heavy flavor with lots of fruit and toffee sweetness. Thick syrupy mouthfeel. A cognac-like feeling to this reminds me of the Thomas Hardy Ale.

Clear golden with a large off white head. Sweet aroma with toasted malt, caramel and alcohol. Flavour went the same way. Somewhat boozy finish.

Rich and chewy, this has the rich consistency I would expect from a beer of this strength. The aroma is fruity and the flavour predominantly malty at first. Bottle from Frederikshavn.
Ruby beer, fruity aroma. Rich, maly, vinous. Sour cherries, redcurrants. Quite complex, but not as outstanding as the cask version.

Poured an oaky amber red with a good white head. Flavoursome bitter, a little sour  the aftertaste. Alcoholic in finish. Quite floral but dominated by bitterness. Excellent taste. All round good beer.

Dark amber in colour with an ample-sized, oranged-tinted head. Predominant aromas consist of a heavenly malty sweetness, accompanied by spicy and fruity tones. Clear coppery red body with a minimal lasting head.  Full smooth malt aroma almost full body, caramel notes mainly with a light grainy finish. Wasn’t expecting a lot but was pleasanty surprised.

Rerate 31.12.2008: Noticed some grapefruit and more pine, very American flavors to find in an English ale. Pretty good though.

It’s all wrapped in a luscious malt sweetness and oily ’heirloom orange’ hop flavour that reminds me of old school Old 95 - hints of liquorice and cough medicine too (in the most pleasant way). sweet full, typical. Looks grat, pretty good head too. Strong, but more quickly guzzled & palettable than the Belgian - not quite as good, but a damn good effort.

amazingly rich treacle, toffee and malt in the nose, Poured a slightly hazy coppery red, palate is dominated by flavour hops, which detracted form the thick sweetness a little, dare I say I would have preferred this if it had a little less hops..
Bottle at ÅBF08. Clear dark amber colour. Sweet flavour. Very malty with some alcohol. Not as interesting as hoped.

Bottle at Victoria, Strathearn Place. Clear amber colour with large creamy off-white mostly lasting head. Fruity aroma. Sweet fruity flavor.

500ml bottle picked up at Sainsburys, TCR, London. Deep mahogany body covered by a thin layer, displaying nice laceworks. Dark fruity and nutty aroma. Pungent hop resin in flavour supported by anise and berries. Moderate bitter ending with a noticeable touch of alcohol. Perfect transition from smell to taste. Full bodied (a joy to drink at my hotel room, St Giles 30.04.2008)

Bottle at The Artillery Arms, London. Pours amber with a medium yellowish head. Quite flowery hop aroma. Fruity, nutty and perfumy flavours, matched by good bitterness. Medium carbonation, quite full-bodied. Delicious.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2008 Fitting toast to Beckhams anticlimactic 100th cap in Paris. Bronze ringed with white. Some enticing stemmy green orange/juniper hop notes on the nose, sweetly citrussy with plenty of caramelised malt back-up a bit like a mellow IPA. Flavour marred by too much coarse antiseptic alcohol, whiskeyish booze, and (agian) a dead lingering bitterness presumably the by-product of filtering/pasteurisation. Completely unaromatic. If thats a word. Vaguely pleasant toffeeish notes, but smothered with sickly, buttery almond (ethanol). A very fine line indeed between this and Bavaria Red/RIP/ Exterminator-type malt liquors served in a brown paper bag. Dead barley wine ruined by pasteurisation and too much booze. I couldnt finish it.

Beautiful dark amber (almost reddish) with an off wihte head. Sweet aroma of peach, caramel and melon.
